Did he get jump wings. ------------------------------------------------ Taken from a dog book #3 German Shepherd The German Shepherd was originally bred specifically for intelligence. Smart, courageous, and protective, the Shepherd is one of the most dependable of companions. They learn tasks after only a few repetitions, and obey first commands nearly always the first time it is given. They are eager to learn new tasks, as this gives them direction and purpose—very important for a Shepherd. Besides being used for herding animals, they are often used as guard dogs, police dogs, search-and-rescue dogs, and have even been trained by the military for parachute jumps.

title: C"mon German Shepards aren't dumb enough

content: I have worked with and trained a lot of shepards. They can be as any other dawg depending on breeding, care, teaching and the owner. You put all of that together and you have the dawg as a grown up animal. Only then can you say if they are smart. Most I have to say are very good at anything you teach them. Information in, information out. I have a black Lab that will stand toe to toe to any Shepard or I should say most. There are some real smart Shepards. You can't say any breed is smarter or better. it all depends on what they are doing. SHEP HERD, that's what they were for. Not anymore. Too much to say to list in a post here. My final thought.... You cannot say any type of any animal in a side breed is smarter than another. Too many factors fall into place when you make that judgement. MD
reply: I have worked with and trained a lot of shepards. They can be as any other dawg depending on breeding, care, teaching and the owner. content: German Shepherd Dog History Derived from the old breeds of herding and farm dogs, and associated for centuries with man as servant and companion, the German Shepherd Dog has been subject to intensive development. Sponsored by the Verein fur Deutsche Schaferhunde, the parent club of the breed founded in 1899 in Germany, the cult of the Shepherd spread rapidly from about 1914 onward in many parts of the world. Interest in the breed has been fostered by specialty clubs in many lands as it has been in the United States by the German Shepherd Dog Club of America.

content: quote: You cannot say any type of any animal in a side breed is smarter than another. Too many factors fall into place when you make that judgement. Sure I can. Ever own an Irish Setter? Dumb with a capital 'D'. Once had one who would sit when you told him.... for at least twenty minutes... in the rain... and nothing you could do would cause him to move from the spot. Granted, they are a happy breed and wonderful pets. But I have yet to see one whose IQ ranked above a bag of hammers. Sullivan013

content: quote: Originally posted by sullivan013: quote: You cannot say any type of any animal in a side breed is smarter than another. Too many factors fall into place when you make that judgement. Sure I can. Ever own an Irish Setter? Dumb with a capital 'D'. Once had one who would sit when you told him.... for at least twenty minutes... in the rain... and nothing you could do would cause him to move from the spot. Granted, they are a happy breed and wonderful pets. But I have yet to see one whose IQ ranked above a bag of hammers. Sullivan013 "Bad" thing about setters is that if they go to point in dense country, forget it... You'll never see the dog again unless the bird jumps or you blunder onto the dog by shear luck. They'll set motionless 'til they drop dead - - The last dog I had would get bored with setting. If you didn't get there real quick, he'd just grab the pheasant and bring it to ya. Then he'd go to the truck and wouldn't want to hunt any more - like owning a damned mule! Miss him - - Wandering and Wondering

content: German Shepherd Dog History Derived from the old breeds of herding and farm dogs, and associated for centuries with man as servant and companion, the German Shepherd Dog has been subject to intensive development. Sponsored by the Verein fur Deutsche Schaferhunde, the parent club of the breed founded in 1899 in Germany, the cult of the Shepherd spread rapidly from about 1914 onward in many parts of the world. Interest in the breed has been fostered by specialty clubs in many lands as it has been in the United States by the German Shepherd Dog Club of America.

content: quote: You cannot say any type of any animal in a side breed is smarter than another. Too many factors fall into place when you make that judgement. Sure I can. Ever own an Irish Setter? Dumb with a capital 'D'. Once had one who would sit when you told him.... for at least twenty minutes... in the rain... and nothing you could do would cause him to move from the spot. Granted, they are a happy breed and wonderful pets. But I have yet to see one whose IQ ranked above a bag of hammers. Sullivan013
quote: You cannot say any type of any animal in a side breed is smarter than another. Too many factors fall into place when you make that judgement.

Granted, they are a happy breed and wonderful pets. But I have yet to see one whose IQ ranked above a bag of hammers. Sullivan013

content: quote: Originally posted by sullivan013: quote: You cannot say any type of any animal in a side breed is smarter than another. Too many factors fall into place when you make that judgement. Sure I can. Ever own an Irish Setter? Dumb with a capital 'D'. Once had one who would sit when you told him.... for at least twenty minutes... in the rain... and nothing you could do would cause him to move from the spot. Granted, they are a happy breed and wonderful pets. But I have yet to see one whose IQ ranked above a bag of hammers. Sullivan013 "Bad" thing about setters is that if they go to point in dense country, forget it... You'll never see the dog again unless the bird jumps or you blunder onto the dog by shear luck. They'll set motionless 'til they drop dead - - The last dog I had would get bored with setting. If you didn't get there real quick, he'd just grab the pheasant and bring it to ya. Then he'd go to the truck and wouldn't want to hunt any more - like owning a damned mule! Miss him - - Wandering and Wondering

content: I have a friend who trains dogs, and she says for overall learning ability the poodle and the border collie are the easiest to train. However, you can train almost any breed, I guess it depends on the technique. I remember visiting a friend whose family had a royal poodle, it was huge, and he did some amazing tricks. My Uncles have always had border collies because they are herding dogs, along with corgis etc.
